data.title: MASONIC TEMPLE.
data.meta_description: The new Masonic Memorial Temple in Ann-street, one of the most inspiring and majestic buildings in the city, will be dedicated ...
data.text:
The new Masonic Memorial

Temple In Ann-street, one of the

most Inspiring and majestic build-

ings In the city, will be dedicated

and formally opened next week,

when prominent Freemasons from

all parts of the Commonwealth will

be present at the ceremonies.

The outside of a building does not

necessarily give an Indication of ita

interior; but in the case of the new

Temple the noble exterior gives the

key-note to the magnificence of the

internal arrangements and handsome

appointments. The finishing touches

are now being put to the inside

decorations, and an official inspection

was made yesterday.

The facade of the building is im-

mensely imposing, with its six fluted,

massive Corinthian columns, 5ft. In

diameter, rising base to summit of the

three-story structure, and the first

glimpse obtained of the vestibule

through the main entrance Is indeed

a striking one and a fitting introduc-

tion to the splendour of the Grand

Lodge Room on the top floor. The

main entrance gives on to a circular

vestibule, in the very centre of which

is an immense urn of pinkish marble,

mounted on a massive square pedestal

of black marble. Inside the urn, in-

visible from the exterior, is a powerful

electric light, which throws its rays

upwards, flooding the white canopy of

ceiling in a bath of soft white light.

The effect is inspiring to a degree. On

the black base are inscribed lines from

a verse by E. W. H. Fowles:

Brethren beloved! your hearts or gold

From us no time can sever;

Dauntless, you leapt to heights untold;

Dying, you live for ever.

Opening out from the vestibule and

from a corridor extending to the rear

of the building are the executive

offices, the board room, the Grand

Master's reception room, secretary's

office, and committee rooms. The

board room is a spacious chamber,

with a large table in the shape of a

keystone. The furnishings and ap-

pointments are of silky oak. The

Grand Master's reception room Is

handsomely furnished in Queensland

maple, mahogany-stained, whilst the

floors of all the rooms are of par-

quetry. The vestibule and corridors

are paved with marble mosaic in the

Old Roman style, which is decidedly

artistic and most effective.

USEFUL LODGE ROOMS.

The first floor is devoted solely to

lodge rooms, of which there are four.

Two of them are large rooms, capable

of accommodating about 250 brethren,

whilst the smaller rooms have seating

capacity for about 80 each. Each

lodge room has convenient dressing

rooms attached. All the lodge rooms,

as well as passages and dressing

rooms, are furnished throughout in

silky oak, and the flooring is of par-

quetry.

The second floor is entirely taken
